data.title: Vince Ellis' farewell: Despite no playoff wins, Detroit Pistons were compelling
data.meta_description: After 11½ seasons covering the Detroit Pistons, Vince Ellis says goodbye and remembers his time on the beat
data.text:
In the summer of 2008, I was asked to fill in for Krista Jahnke.

At the time, I was a general assignment reporter, mostly covering high schools and small colleges.

Jahnke, who took a temporary absence to have a child, covered the Detroit Pistons.

The team was easy to babysit. The Pistons were coming off six straight appearances in the Eastern Conference finals with the core of Chauncey Billups, Rasheed Wallace, Rip Hamilton, Tayshaun Prince and Antonio McDyess still firmly in place.

The only signings that summer?

The Pistons acquired free agents Will Bynum, Kwame Brown and Walter Hermann, which was light work for me while performing other responsibilities at the Free Press.

Jahnke returned, but decided to relinquish Pistons duties.

Without an interview, former sports editor Gene Myers decided I would cover the Pistons in late September.

The next day, a bus carrying first-year coach Michael Curry, promising guard Rodney Stuckey and media members left for a two-day trip to Michigan’s west side, an annual effort from the franchise to create interest around the state.

I never aspired to cover the Pistons; it just happened.

And after 11½ seasons as a fill-in, it’s time for the Free Press to find a permanent replacement.

I can guess the immediate thoughts of those reading this:

“You are the problem!”

Yeah, it has been a time of losing.

I only covered three playoff appearances and never covered a playoff victory.

The franchise has an ongoing 14-game postseason losing streak (I covered the last 13 losses since I was there for the Game 6 loss to the Boston Celtics in the 2008 Eastern Conference finals).

Change has been constant.

After nearly 30 years in northern Oakland County, the Pistons moved from the Palace to newly built Little Caesars Arena in downtown Detroit in 2017.

A state-of-the-art franchise headquarters, located a short distance away in the New Center area, quickly followed.

There were two ownership changes.

I covered three front office leaders.

Seven coaches ran the Pistons under my watch.

Yeah, it hasn’t been pretty.

But despite the losing, it has been a compelling period to chronicle.

No. 1 change

One of the most memorable days occurred early in my tenure.

The Pistons were 2-0 and were in Charlotte for the third game of the season in early November 2008.

In those days, media members arrived at arenas before the team, and I remember standing there with former MLive.com reporter A. Sherrod Blakely and Detroit News reporter Chris McCosky.

As the players walked by, my colleagues both realized something was amiss.

Billups and McDyess were missing.

Within minutes, the word was out: The Pistons were trading Billups, McDyess and Cheikh Samb (remember him?) to the Denver Nuggets for superstar Allen Iverson.

While McCosky and Blakely mobilized to report on the blockbuster, I was completely blind.

No sources to speak with; no bars inside Time Warner Cable Arena to call a source even if I had sources.

Luckily, by the time I arrived back to my hotel room, the Free Press had ignored my worthless presence and had a story on our website courtesy of columnists Michael Rosenberg, who now writes for Sports Illustrated, and Drew Sharp, who died in 2016.

I recall the moment for several reasons: The Iverson acquisition serves as the tipping point to usher in the current era of losing fortunes.

It was also one of the last stories that I didn’t hear first from Twitter.

The idea that a reporter would break news on a social media platform – and not on his/her publication website – was still in its infancy.

But obviously social media has become more than a news vehicle. It has become a way for fans to interact with media members and hold us accountable if we get something wrong.

It may come as a surprise to some who follow me on Twitter, but I enjoy the back and forth – as long as a follower isn’t insulting.

Feel free to continue hitting me up on Twitter. I'll be around.

What I will miss

Traveling to 27 markets around the country is nice, but that cuts both ways. For every trip to Miami, there were trips into potential blizzard-like conditions in Milwaukee or Minneapolis.

The seasons are long, and the games tend to run together, which isn’t surprising since I’m a casual NBA fan.

But I will miss the relationships.

Reporters spend a lot of time waiting for players and coaches, and that leads to many jokes and fun times over the years with folks you see more often than family members.

First it was Blakely and McCosky.

Former Detroit News reporter Vincent Goodwill, who now works for Yahoo! Sports, is still a good friend.

And I will miss seeing The Athletic’s James Edwards, The Detroit News’ Rod Beard and Pistons.com’s Keith Langlois in the media room at the Pistons Performance Center.

But all things end.

I plan to hang around Detroit. If you see me out, please say hello.

Take care.
